snippet: Joseph J. Lhota and Bill de Blasio embraced the role of fierce rivals on Thursday, even as thousands of ballots from New York City’s mayoral primary had yet to be counted.
abstract: Joseph J Lhota and Bill de Blasio embrace role of fierce rivals, displaying testy tenor and deep ideological divide of a general election matchup even as thousands of ballots from New York City’s mayoral primary have yet to be counted; Lhota, campaigning for first time since securing Republican nomination, promises to take down his likely opponent, accusing de Blasio of dividing New Yorkers.

byline.original: By MICHAEL M. GRYNBAUM, THOMAS KAPLAN and JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
byline.contributor: Michael Barbaro, David W. Chen and Sarah Maslin Nir contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: Joseph J. Lhota and Bill de Blasio embraced the role of fierce rivals on Thursday, even as thousands of ballots from New York City’s mayoral primary had yet to be counted.

headline.main: After Mayoral Primaries, a Sharp Divide
headline.print_headline: After Mayoral Primaries, a Sharp Divide
